Run-of-river hydroelectricity is a type of hydroelectric power generation that harnesses the natural flow of a river to generate electricity. It does not require the construction of a dam or reservoir, making it a more environmentally friendly option.
relations.Subject: run-of-river hydroelectricity

relations.Description: Reservoir hydroelectricity is a type of hydroelectric power generation that involves the construction of a dam and reservoir. The water stored in the reservoir is released through turbines to generate electricity. It provides a reliable and controllable source of renewable energy.
relations.Subject: reservoir hydroelectricity

relations.Description: Pumped-storage hydroelectricity is a type of hydroelectric power generation that uses two reservoirs at different elevations. During periods of low electricity demand, excess electricity is used to pump water from the lower reservoir to the upper reservoir. During periods of high demand, the stored water is released to generate electricity.
relations.Subject: pumped-storage hydroelectricity

relations.Description: Tidal hydroelectricity is a type of hydroelectric power generation that harnesses the energy of tides. It involves the construction of barrages or tidal turbines in coastal areas with significant tidal ranges. Tidal energy is a predictable and renewable source of electricity.
relations.Subject: tidal hydroelectricity

relations.Description: Wave hydroelectricity is a type of hydroelectric power generation that captures the energy of ocean waves. It utilizes devices such as wave buoys or oscillating water columns to convert the mechanical energy of waves into electricity. Wave energy has the potential to provide a consistent and renewable source of power.
relations.Subject: wave hydroelectricity
